name: Newgrange
shortDescription: Ancient passage tomb and sacred site, aligned with winter solstice, dwelling of the Dagda and Aengus
fullDescription: Newgrange (Irish: SÃ­ an BhrÃº or BrÃº na BÃ³inne) is a massive Neolithic passage tomb in Ireland's Boyne Valley, older than Stonehenge and the Egyptian pyramids. In Irish mythology, it was known as the dwelling place of the Dagda and later his son Aengus Ã“g. The monument is precisely aligned so that on the winter solstice, sunlight penetrates the passage and illuminates the inner chamber, representing rebirth and the return of light. It serves as a gateway between the mortal world and the otherworld.

events.name: Aengus Tricks the Dagda
events.description: Aengus Ã“g tricks his father the Dagda into giving him permanent possession of Newgrange by asking for it for 'a day and a night,' which in Irish idiom means forever

events.name: Winter Solstice Illumination
events.description: Each winter solstice, the rising sun aligns perfectly with the passage, illuminating the inner chamber and symbolizing the rebirth of light and the year

mythologyContexts.usage: Sacred dwelling of the Tuatha DÃ© Danann, entrance to the otherworld, site of cosmic rebirth rituals. The winter solstice alignment marks the astronomical knowledge and spiritual significance of the site

textReferences.context: Describes the BrÃº as the dwelling of the Dagda and Aengus

textReferences.passage: The Fosterage of the House of the Two Milk Vessels
textReferences.context: Aengus tricks the Dagda to gain possession of the BrÃº

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents the womb of the earth, death and rebirth, the solar cycle, and the gateway between worlds. The passage and chamber symbolize the journey from darkness to light, from death to rebirth. The triple spiral carvings represent the sacred three-fold nature of Celtic cosmology.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Newgrange is one of the most important archaeological sites in Ireland, demonstrating the astronomical sophistication and spiritual depth of Neolithic Irish culture. It remained sacred through the Celtic period and into modern times, bridging prehistoric and mythological Ireland.

sources.passage: The Fosterage of the House of the Two Milk Vessels
